New Construction Activity Slows in September, Primarily in Multi-Family Space
September 2024 New Residential Construction
 
What happened
New residential construction retreated slightly in September following a strong August. The number of units permitted for construction fell to 1,428,000 on a seasonally adjusted annual basis, a decrease of 2.9% from the previous month and 5.7% from the previous year. Housing starts slowed as well, falling 0.5% from August 2024 and 0.7% from September 2023. Completions dipped by 2.7% month-over-month, but remain up by 14.6% year-over-year. After leading the surge in August, multi-family projects dragged in September. Permits fell 10.8% month-over-month and 17.4% year-over-year, starts fell 4.5% month-over-month and 15.7% year-over-year, and completions fell 8.7% month-over-month though they remain elevated from 2023 figures. After 14 months of consecutive declines in median asking rent, builders seem to be responding to the market and shifting their focus to single-family construction. 

 
Where it happened
This month’s data contains some eye-popping regional splits, mostly in the Northeast, which this team of economists suggests should be taken with a grain of salt. Housing starts in the Northeast are up 57.9% month-over-month and 109.3% year-over-year for September, the same month in which the region’s first snowfall occurred. Completions too were up 55.6% month-over-month and 92.2% year-over-year on a seasonally adjusted annual basis. Blips in the raw data during off-peak months of the year in regions with a high degree of seasonality, like the Northeast, can skew the adjusted figures that are primarily reported. We will be interested to see how next month’s revisions of the September data come in. 
Meanwhile, the majority (51.0%) of newly-built homes hitting the market are still in the South, where September completions fell 21.6% from the spike month in August, but still exceed September of last year by 3.1%. The West region had a strong month in terms of housing completions, beating August by 22.1% and last September by 25.3%. On a permitting basis, the South also dominates in terms of future construction, constituting 53.6% of permits issued nationally. Southern states make up most of the top 10 states for new construction highlighted in our New Construction Insights Report, and it appears that trend will continue.
What does this mean for homebuyers, sellers, homeowners, and the housing market
Prospective homebuyers are facing major affordability challenges, with mortgage rates ticking back up into the mid-6% range and listing prices remaining stubbornly high. Though the bottom-line new construction figures for September 2024 are somewhat disappointing, single-family projects specifically had a more promising month. Single-family permits and starts were up from even a strong August, and single-family completions still exceeded September 2023. Builders are increasingly bringing smaller, more affordable homes to the market, so buyers may find more newly-built homes that fit their budget in the coming years if the pace of new construction continues.
Sign up for updates
Join our mailing list to receive the latest data and research.

Document1.context: Percentage decrease in miles traveled
Percentage decrease in daily VMT per capita

Document2.context: Percentage increase month-over-month

tasks.question: In Spring 2024, Minneapolis had a 16% decrease in miles traveled, San Francisco had a 13% decrease in daily VMT per capita, and in September 2024, the Northeast saw a 57.9% increase in housing starts. If we subtract the decrease in Minneapolis from the increase in the Northeast and then divide the result by San Francisco's decrease, what is the final value?
tasks.solution:
def solve():
    # Extracted numerical values from the document
    minneapolis_decrease = 16  # Percentage decrease in miles traveled
    san_francisco_decrease = 13  # Percentage decrease in daily VMT per capita
    northeast_increase = 57.9  # Percentage increase in housing starts

    # Step 1: Subtract Minneapolis decrease from Northeast increase
    intermediate_result = northeast_increase - minneapolis_decrease

    # Step 2: Divide the result by San Francisco's decrease
    answer = intermediate_result / san_francisco_decrease

    return answer

document: HIGH-CAPACITY ROADWAY STUDY • ALTERNATIVES MEMORANDUM • AUGUST 2024 1 HIGH-CAPACITY ROADWAY ALTERNATIVES MEMORANDUM DATE: August 14, 2024 TO: Darrell West | Bonneville MPO DaNeil Jose | Bonneville MPO FROM: Aaron Berger, PE | DKS Associates SUBJECT: BMPO High-Capacity Roadways Study Project #22174-000 This memorandum summarizes the process used to identify, evaluate, and select the recommended high-capacity roadway system for the BMPO area. The memo includes: • Summary of Prior Work – Baseline Needs Evaluation Summary, Study Purpose and Need Statement, and summary Public Outreach completed to date • Alternatives Development and Evaluation – process and outcomes from expressway and strategic arterial concept development and evaluation of alternatives • Recommendations – Presents the recommended new expressways and strategic arterials, including recommended changes to functional classification throughout the BMPO area SUMMARY OF PRIOR WORK The work completed during the High-Capacity Roadway Study (HCRS) to date is summarized in the following sections: • Baseline Needs Evaluation Summary • Purpose and Need Statement • Public Outreach Summary BASELINE NEEDS EVALUATION SUMMARY The baseline needs for the BMPO area roadway system are described in detail in the Baseline Conditions and Needs Technical Memorandum.1 The needs evaluation used the BMPO travel demand model for years 2022 (existing), 2035, and 2050 conditions, flagging key congested corridors throughout the region. This evaluation included planned projects from the LRTP through the year 2050, including widening projects on several arterial corridors and the I-15 to US 20 Connector (see Figure 1). These Baseline projects were documented in the study Methods and 1 BMPO HCRS Baseline Conditions and Needs and Technical Memorandum, September 2023 HIGH-CAPACITY ROADWAY STUDY • ALTERNATIVES MEMORANDUM • AUGUST 2024 2 Assumptions Memorandum.2 The planning level cost estimates for these proposed improvements total $325 Million, excluding the cost of the I-15 to US 20 Connector, The I-15/US20 connector project was included in the modelling. FIGURE 1: BMPO BASELINE PROJECTS (2022, 2035, 2050) 2 BMPO HCRS Methods and Assumptions Memo, March 2023 HIGH-CAPACITY ROADWAY STUDY • ALTERNATIVES MEMORANDUM • AUGUST 2024 3 The future traffic conditions of the BMPO area were forecasted based on the demographic projections and baseline network assumptions presented in Baseline Conditions Memorandum. The needs analysis focused on the year 2050 Baseline Conditions. To identify levels of congestion and network constraints, estimate traffic Level of Service (LOS) was used to compare the daily traffic volumes to the roadway capacity, based on roadway type and number of lanes. The 2050 Baseline BMPO model LOS and estimated Average Daily Traffic (ADT) volumes are summarized in Figure 2. FIGURE 2: 2050 BASELINE LOS AND ADT As shown in Figure 2, the BMPO Area is expected to experience increased congestion in the future, even with assumed significant investment in expanding and adding to existing roadways. System wide, drivers in the BMPO Area are forecasted to experience 82% more delay per trip by the year 2050. HIGH-CAPACITY ROADWAY STUDY • ALTERNATIVES MEMORANDUM • AUGUST 2024 4 The BMPO Area system wide levels of congested roadway, LOS E (at capacity) and LOS F (over capacity) are summarized by lane miles in Table 1. TABLE 1: CONGESTED LANE MILES SUMMARY YEAR % LANE MILES LOS E % LANE MILES LOS F % LANE MILES DEFICIENT (LOS E AND F) 2022 2.6% 1.9% 4.5% 2050 8.3% 6.9% 15.2% As shown in Table 1, by the year 2050 the total miles of congested roadway within the BMPO area roadway system is estimated to more than triple, despite the improvements assumed in the 2050 Baseline Scenario to include the projects in the LRTP. The primary areas of need identified in the Baseline Needs analysis include: • Existing and future congestion on segments of critical arterial corridors such as: o 17th Street (both existing and future conditions) o Ammon Road (both existing and future conditions) o Iona Road (both existing and future conditions) o 5th East (both existing and future conditions) o Lincoln Road (future conditions) o 25th East (future conditions) o Sunnyside Road (future conditions) o 5th West (future conditions) • Constrained East-West river crossings, including 2050 daily traffic demand projected to increase by 94% over present-day conditions, include: o Broadway (LOS D) o Pancheri (LOS F) o Sunnyside (LOS E) o 65th S (LOS D with assumed widening of the existing bridge to double capacity) • The Sunnyside Road/I-15 Interchange – trips using the interchange are expected to increase from 17,000 to 45,000 per day by the year 2050. This increase includes the baseline assumption that the 65th S bridge is widened. Without this project, Sunnyside Interchange traffic would increase even more. • Traffic growth on rural roads towards the foothills to the East, including the rural segments of Sunnyside Road, 17th Street 45th East, Ammon Road, and 65th South are expected to exceed capacity due to the growth projected in the southern portion of the BMPO Area. PROJECT PURPOSE AND NEEDS STATEMENT The roadway congestion needs identified in the Future Baseline Evaluation were combined with other identified needs including safety, access, and active transportation themes from the most HIGH-CAPACITY ROADWAY STUDY • ALTERNATIVES MEMORANDUM • AUGUST 2024 5 recent BMPO LRTP to create the High-Capacity Roadway Study (HCRS) Needs Statement, as follows: “Lack of safe, efficient, and equitable access for all modes of travel from new growth areas within the BMPO area to regional activity centers and highway facilities, with increasing pass-through travel on congested arterial corridors.” Based on the study needs statement, the HCRS Purpose Statement was then defined as follows: “Proactively plan and develop comprehensive multi-modal high-capacity roadway corridors and supporting connections, optimizing future transportation investments to help alleviate traffic congestion on existing arterial corridors and enhance overall regional mobility.” Both the Purpose and Need Statements establish the approach to the alternatives development process. PUBLIC OUTREACH SUMMARY The Exiting and Future Baseline system evaluation results and study Purpose and Need Statement were shared with the Public in an Open House event on November 14, 2023. Public feedback from this event identified the following additional key themes: • Lack of active transportation facilities • Congestion on arterial corridors, particularly Ammon Road • Pass/Cut-thru traffic on local streets • Need for coordinated signal timing on arterials • Utility of roundabouts on arterials • Speeding on rural arterials • Need for beltway system to reduce congestion These needs were also considered where applicable to the project purpose statement during the subsequent alternatives screening and evaluation process. ALTERNATIVES DEVELOPMENT AND EVALUATION The alternatives development and evaluation process followed four distinct steps: 1. Develop initial Expressway Alternatives 2. Fatal Flaw (Level 1) Screening of Expressway Alternatives (with the Steering Committee only or including elected officials?) Concern was expressed by elected officials in the last Joint TAC Police Board meeting giving indicators that we might have to go back to this step 3. Evaluation (Level 2) of Expressway Alternatives 4. Develop and Evaluate Strategic Arterial Alternatives HIGH-CAPACITY ROADWAY STUDY • ALTERNATIVES MEMORANDUM • AUGUST 2024 6 INITIAL EXPRESSWAY ALTERNATIVES An expressway is a limited access, median-separated, high speed (55 mph or more) facility. US 20 through Idaho Falls currently operates as an expressway facility. Expressways may include grade separations/interchanges, particularly in urbanized areas, but can also be full access at-grade intersections, albeit spaced at 1-mile minimum distances. An expressway will contain a minimum of two lanes per direction. The initial expressway alternatives were developed using a combination of ideas from the Steering Committee, project team, and the public, as well as concepts proposed in the “Idaho Falls Arterial Loop: Economic Assessment” and the “Transportation System Alternatives Study.” These expressway concepts were intended to serve future growth areas surrounding the currently urbanized BMPO areas while also providing higher speed, higher capacity alternatives to existing congested arterial corridors. Note that by nature of their proposed locations, the expressways would not be expected to provide significant relief to current congestion issues in the more fully built out areas within the BMPO, as the new facilities would be too far out of direction to pull trips from these roadways. The expressway alternatives were intended to provide both capacity for new development and increase resiliency of nearby congested arterials against future growth. The following initial Expressway Alternatives were proposed for Level 1 Screening (See Figure 3): • North Concept o North Expressway Alternative 1 – New Expressway located approximately on the 81st North Alignment, from I-15 to US 26. This concept would include a new interchange on I-15 and a new Snake River crossing. • South Concepts o South Expressway Alternative 1 – New Expressway located approximately along the 65th South existing alignment, from I-15 to 45th East (Crowley). This concept would involve re-aligning the 65th South Corridor between 15th East and 25th East. o South Expressway Alternative 2 – New Expressway located approximately halfway between 65th South and 81st South, connecting I-15 to 45th East (Crowley). This alternative would follow the 65th South existing alignment from I-15 through US 91. o South Expressway Alternative 3 – New Expressway located approximately along the 65th South existing alignment, but routing to the north-east at 25th East, ultimately connecting to 45th East (Crowley) near Sunnyside Road. This concept is identical to South Expressway Alternative 1 from I-15 to 25th East. • East o East Expressway Alternative 1 – New Expressway located approximately ¼ mile east of 55th East, from just north of the 65th South/45th East (Crowley) intersection to the US 26/55th East intersection. • West o West Expressway Alternative 1 – New Expressway connecting the planned I-15/US 20 Connector system interchange to the I-15/45th West/65th South interchange. This alignment would approximately follow the existing 45th West alignment from 17th North to 65th South. HIGH-CAPACITY ROADWAY STUDY • ALTERNATIVES MEMORANDUM • AUGUST 2024 7 Note that these initial concepts were very high-level planning alignments, and more specific details related to the alignment locations and geometry were saved for alternatives passing the subsequent Level 1 (Fatal Flaw) Screening. FIGURE 3: INITIAL EXPRESSWAY CONCEPTS HIGH-CAPACITY ROADWAY STUDY • ALTERNATIVES MEMORANDUM • AUGUST 2024 8 Two additional alternatives were considered and dismissed based on clear feasibility constraints: • 45th East Expressway (65th S to US 26) – the existing land use, constrained ROW, and access conditions on this corridor led to this alternative being deemed infeasible by the Stakeholder Committee • 55th East Expressway (45th E near 65th S to US 26) – similar to 45th East, the constrained ROW, and access conditions on this corridor led to this alternative being deemed infeasible by the Stakeholder Committee EXPRESSWAY ALTERNATIVES LEVEL 1 SCREENING The HCRS Streeting Committee performed the Level 1 (Fatal Flaw) Screening of the initial expressway alternatives. The key Level 1 Screening Criteria considered were: • Physical Constraints – consideration of prohibitive terrain features such as steep grades • Traffic Utility – consideration of the project purpose and need related to identified congestion needs • ROW/property Impacts – Potential to create large scale property acquisitions in already built out neighborhoods and subdivisions • Access Impacts – existing roadway and driveway access for expressway alignments following current roadway corridors Using these criteria, the Steering Committee screened out the following expressway alternatives: • North Expressway Alternative 1 – This concept was screened out due to minimal anticipated traffic utility towards the HCRS Purpose and Need. Under 2050 Baseline Conditions, the I-15 to US 20 Connector project provides surplus capacity for east-west traffic in this area, and the proposed expressway corridor would not be targeting any clear needs. In addition, the ROW impacts along 81st N and the feasibility of constructing another system level interchange on I-15 were determining factors in screening out this alternative. • South Expressway Alternative 1 – This alternative was screened out due to access impacts along the existing 65th South corridor, which includes many driveways and already abuts housing subdivision connections. • South Expressway Alternative 3 – This alternative was also screened out due to access impacts along the existing 65th South corridor as well as conflicts with subdivisions when connecting from 65th south across Ammon Road and onto 49th East (Crowley) • East Expressway Alternative 1 – This alternative was screened out due to property impacts and grade constraints for the segment from 45th East to the proposed north-south alignment, particularly conflicts at Sunnyside Road The remaining Expressway Alternatives (South Expressway Alternative 2 and West Expressway Alternative 1) were advanced to the Level 2 Evaluation. EXPRESSWAY ALTERNATIVES LEVEL 2 EVALUATION The two expressway alternatives advanced to the Level 2 Evaluation (South Alt 2 and West Alt 1) were analyzed in the 2050 BMPO travel demand model to estimate the potential traffic benefits and independent utility of these proposed corridors. Each corridor was also evaluated to determine the HIGH-CAPACITY ROADWAY STUDY • ALTERNATIVES MEMORANDUM • AUGUST 2024 9 high-level key design constraints and potential ROW, access, and design challenges that the proposed expressway would likely entail. WEST EXPRESSWAY ALTERNATIVE EVALUATION The West Expressway Alignment was refined to include curves that met AASHTO standards for the anticipated speeds (55 mph) of the new facility. The northern terminus of the proposed expressway was connected to the yet to be constructed I-15/US 20 Connector as the fourth leg of the system interchange. At the southern terminus, the expressway follows the 45th W alignment into the 65th S/I-15 interchange. The West Expressway Alternative was added to the BMPO 2050 Baseline network and run as an independent scenario under 2050 conditions. As this was a high-level evaluation of the viability of this proposed expressway, the initial coding assumptions emphasized capacity, speed, and throughput. These coding assumptions do not represent the likely expressway configuration but do portray the ability of the proposed facility to draw trips away from other congested corridors. The arterial intersections with the proposed expressway were either modeled as grade separations (overpass/underpass) or interchanges, described as follows: • Old Butte Rd/N 26th W – Coded as an overpass/underpass • 35th W – Coded as an interchange • 57th W – Coded as an overpass/underpass • W 17th N – Coded as an interchange • US 20 – Coded as an interchange • 17th Street S – Coded as an overpass/underpass • W 33rd S – Coded as an interchange • W 49th S – Coded as an overpass/underpass To better understand the traffic benefits of the West Expressway Alternative, the change in daily traffic volume between the year 2050 West Expressway Alternative and the Baseline Scenario was mapped and analyzed (See Figure 4). HIGH-CAPACITY ROADWAY STUDY • ALTERNATIVES MEMORANDUM • AUGUST 2024 10 FIGURE 4: WEST EXPRESSWAY VS BASELINE 2050 TRAFFIC VOLUME CHANGE As shown in Figure 4, the West Expressway draws traffic away from the I-15 and US 20 West, reducing daily traffic on these corridors by up to 15%. The expressway essentially provides a US 20 bypass around Idaho Falls. The expressway also pulls traffic away from the congested I-15/Sunnyside Road interchange, reducing traffic at this location by 5%. Additional localized increases on roadways such as 33rd S, 49th S, and Broadway are driven be assumed reduced access HIGH-CAPACITY ROADWAY STUDY • ALTERNATIVES MEMORANDUM • AUGUST 2024 11 to the 45th West corridor, which would then reallocate trips to these east-west corridors. Overall, these reallocated future trips are not expected to create significant capacity issues on these east-west corridors. The West Expressway 2050 BMPO model LOS and estimated Average Daily Traffic (ADT) volumes are summarized in Figure 5 (without the South Expressway Alternative). FIGURE 5: 2050 WEST EXPRESSWAY LOS AND ADT As shown in Figure 5, the West Expressway does not directly address any of the critical 2050 Baseline LOS issues. This proposed expressway does provide significant regional route redundancy by providing an alternate US 20 route, and also provides additional capacity to support growth west of the Snake River. HIGH-CAPACITY ROADWAY STUDY • ALTERNATIVES MEMORANDUM • AUGUST 2024 12 A high-level assessment of the corridor for expressway feasibility indicated the challenges summarized in Table 2. TABLE 2: WEST EXPRESSWAY KEY CHALLENGES CHALLENGE SEGMENT POTENTIAL MITIGATIONS PRIVATE DRIVEWAYS 65th S to 49th S Shift expressway alignment west of 45th W ½ Mile south of US 20 Shift expressway alignment slightly west, extend old S 45th Rd W alignment south as a frontage connection CONSTRAINED ROW 17th S/45th W Consider shifting alignment east to bypass existing privates and commercial structures NEW ROW NEEDED 17th N to I-15/US 20 Connector Interchange Refine alignment for this corridor to provide basis for ROW buffer, ensuing future development does not build over the proposed corridor 17th N to 65th S Ensure incoming development along 45th W leaves sufficient ROW setbacks to accommodate an expressway cross section 65th S/I-15 Interchange ROW needs for potential system interchange SOUTH EXPRESSWAY ALTERNATIVE EVALUATION The South Expressway Alignment was refined to include curves that met AASHTO standards for the anticipated speeds (55 mph) of the new facility. The western terminus of the proposed expressway follows the existing 65th S alignment and connects into the 65th S/I-15 interchange. At the eastern terminus, the expressway ties into 45th E (Crowley). The South Expressway Alternative was added to the BMPO 2050 Baseline network and run as an independent scenario under 2050 conditions. As this was a high-level evaluation of the viability of this proposed expressway, similar to the West Expressway, the initial coding assumptions emphasized capacity, speed, and throughput. These coding assumptions do not represent the likely expressway configuration but do portray the ability of the proposed facility to draw trips away from other congested corridors. The arterial intersections with the proposed expressway were either modeled as grade separations (overpass/underpass) or interchanges, described as follows: • 1600 Rd/81 S – Overpass/Underpass • US 91 – Interchange • Jameston Rd – Overpass/Underpass • 5th W – Overpass/Underpass • 5th E (Holmes) – Interchange HIGH-CAPACITY ROADWAY STUDY • ALTERNATIVES MEMORANDUM • AUGUST 2024 13 • 15th E – Overpass/Underpass • 25th E – Interchange • Ammon Rd – Overpass/Underpass In addition, the 65th S/I-15 interchange capacity was assumed to be expanded as part of the South Expressway Alternative, with the existing roundabouts widened to multi-lane and the existing overpass expanded to four lanes. To better understand the traffic benefits of the South Expressway Alternative, both South Expressway Alternative 1 and Alternative 2 were evaluated. South Expressway Alternative 1 was modeled to determine whether shifting the expressway further south significantly decreased the traffic benefits. In addition, the West Expressway Alternative was included with both South Expressway Scenarios to better understand the traffic impacts at the 65th S/I-15 interchange. The change in daily traffic volume between the year 2050 South Expressway Alternative 1, Alternative 2, and the Baseline Scenario are shown in Figure 6 and Figure 7. HIGH-CAPACITY ROADWAY STUDY • ALTERNATIVES MEMORANDUM • AUGUST 2024 14 FIGURE 6: SOUTH EXPRESSWAY ALTERNATIVE 1 VS BASELINE 2050 TRAFFIC VOLUME CHANGE HIGH-CAPACITY ROADWAY STUDY • ALTERNATIVES MEMORANDUM • AUGUST 2024 15 FIGURE 7: SOUTH EXPRESSWAY ALTERNATIVE 2 VS BASELINE 2050 TRAFFIC VOLUME CHANGE HIGH-CAPACITY ROADWAY STUDY • ALTERNATIVES MEMORANDUM • AUGUST 2024 16 As shown in both figures, the south expressway pulls traffic off multiple congested corridors, reducing 2050 traffic demand on Sunnyside Road by approximately 12%, and on 17th Street by approximately 8%. Based on these findings, shifting the south expressway approximately ½ mile south of 65th S was determined to provide similar traffic benefits to the expressway alternative on the existing 65th S alignment. Note that there are additional shifts of north-south traffic between parallel corridors. These shifts are driven by the modeled access points from arterials onto the expressway, and result in some small north-south traffic shifts farther from the expressway, such as on to Woodruff north of 25th S. The South Expressway 2050 BMPO model LOS and estimated Average Daily Traffic (ADT) volumes are summarized in Figure 8. FIGURE 8: 2050 SOUTH EXPRESSWAY LOS AND ADT HIGH-CAPACITY ROADWAY STUDY • ALTERNATIVES MEMORANDUM • AUGUST 2024 17 As shown in Figure 8, the South Expressway reduces future congestion on Sunnyside Road, reducing travel time on this corridor by more than 12%, and on 17th Street by more than 7%. In addition, this alternative reduces traffic demand on the 65th S corridor. A high-level assessment of the corridor for expressway feasibility indicated the challenges summarized in Table 3. TABLE 3: SOUTH EXPRESSWAY KEY CHALLENGES CHALLENGE SEGMENT POTENTIAL MITIGATIONS PLANNED DEVELOPMENT Jameston Rd to 5th West (Ivywood West) Shift alignment south, shift reverse curves west to bypass new subdivision COMMERCIAL ACCESS I-15 to US 91 Provide backage/frontage connections to consolidate access along this segment GEOGRAPHIC CONSTRAINTS Snake River Construct second bridge to double capacity, coordinate with County to determine jurisdiction Gravel pit southeast of US 91/65th S Build interchange at existing US 91/65th S intersection, tighten reverse curves to avoid gravel pit and shift alignment ½ mile south by Jameston Rd CONFLICTS WITH EXISTING LAND USES Fairgrounds Shift alignment further south to bypass Ivywood Platted Development Shift alignment further south to bypass CONFLICTS WITH EXISTING INFRASTRUCTURE S 1st E/5th E curves Shift alignment further south to tie into 1st S with more minimal ROW impacts 65th S/I-15 Interchange Interchange would need to be expanded (multi-lane roundabouts, 4-lane bridge) to accommodate expressway traffic, could need additional ROW if ultimate design is a system interchange NEW ROW NEEDED US 91 to 45th E (Crowley) Refine alignment for this corridor to provide basis for ROW buffer, ensuing future development does not build over the proposed corridor EXPRESSWAY ALTERNATIVES LEVEL 2 EVALUATION Following the evaluation of the expressway alternatives, the project team and Steering Committee identified potential candidate corridors for strategic arterials. Strategic arterials would be five to seven lane roadways, with access limited to ½ mile intersection spacing. Intersections could be HIGH-CAPACITY ROADWAY STUDY • ALTERNATIVES MEMORANDUM • AUGUST 2024 18 signal or roundabout controlled, with roundabout control working particularly well in locations where eliminating access points, particularly existing driveways, is not feasible. The initial strategic arterials proposed for consideration are shown in Figure 9. FIGURE 9: PROPOSED STRATEGIC ARTERIALS HIGH-CAPACITY ROADWAY STUDY • ALTERNATIVES MEMORANDUM • AUGUST 2024 19 The strategic arterials were added to the BMPO 2050 Baseline network and run as an independent scenario under 2050 conditions without expressways. The coding of the proposed corridors consisted of removing/revising centroid connections (neighborhood access) onto the proposed strategic arterials. These changes reflected potential access restrictions along the corridors. Corridor speeds were also increased to reflect reduced intersection impedance. Note that the strategic arterials were first tested independently from the expressways to understand their utility, but the ultimate goal is to have the strategic arterials combined with expressways to serve future traffic needs. To better understand the traffic benefits of the Strategic Arterials, the change in daily traffic volume between the year 2050 Strategic Arterials Alternative and the Baseline Scenario was mapped and analyzed (See Figure 10). HIGH-CAPACITY ROADWAY STUDY • ALTERNATIVES MEMORANDUM • AUGUST 2024 20 FIGURE 10: STRATEGIC ARTERIAL ALTERNATIVE VS BASELINE 2050 TRAFFIC VOLUME CHANGE The strategic arterial corridors draw traffic demand from parallel corridors, with 65th S, Lincoln Rd, 25th E, and 45th E in particular drawing additional traffic demand and providing some relief to adjacent corridors such as Ammon Road (up to 13% reduction) and 1st St (up to 12% reduction). The Strategic Arterial 2050 BMPO model LOS and estimated Average Daily Traffic (ADT) volumes are summarized in Figure 11. HIGH-CAPACITY ROADWAY STUDY • ALTERNATIVES MEMORANDUM • AUGUST 2024 21 FIGURE 11: 2050 STRATEGIC ARTERIAL LOS AND ADT As shown in Figure 11, the Strategic Arterial Alternative improves travel times on the following routes: • 65th S (east of US 91) • 35th W • 45th E HIGH-CAPACITY ROADWAY STUDY • ALTERNATIVES MEMORANDUM • AUGUST 2024 22 • 49th S • 45th N Overall, the strategic arterials provide system wide benefit, and that benefit is further augmented when coupled with the south expressway. A high-level assessment of the corridors for strategic arterial feasibility indicated the following key challenges: • 65th S Corridor Challenges o Driveway access – numerous private driveways, particularly between Ammon Road and 45th E o Local subdivision access, including > Maggie Dr > 9 W > S 9th W > S 12th W > Limousin Ave > Glass Mountain Blvd > Sommer Dr o Land Use – Fairgrounds o Geometry – offset intersection at 25th E • Sunnyside Road Corridor Challenges o Local road access, particularly east of 25th E o Constrained ROW – East of 25th E o Existing private driveway access • Lincoln Road Corridor Challenges o Unknown future tie-in to existing US 20 corridor o Commercial Access points west of 25th E o Private driveway access from 25th E to Ammon Rd • 49th N Corridor Challenges o Need to coordinate with ITD US 26 corridor project, particularly at Beaches Corner o Private driveways from Ammon Rd to 45th E • 33rd N Corridor Challenges o Private driveway access near 26th W/Old Butte Rd • 45th W Corridor Challenges o Private driveway access south of 49th S, near 17th S, south of US 20 • 25th E Corridor Challenges o Commercial access near Iona Road and US 26 o Private accesses north of US 26 • 45th E Corridor Challenges HIGH-CAPACITY ROADWAY STUDY • ALTERNATIVES MEMORANDUM • AUGUST 2024 23 o Limited ROW/canal conflicts, particularly north of Lincoln Rd o Private drive access, particularly for ½ mile south of Iona Rd INITIAL HIGH-CAPACITY ROADWAY SYSTEM The West Expressway was initially recommended for inclusion as an opportunity to provide long-term (30+ year) capacity for growth west of I-15. Based on this recommendation, 45th W and 33rd N were not initially recommended as strategic arterials. The South Expressway was initially recommended for inclusion in the high-capacity roadway system due to both the 25-year benefits to adjacent corridors such as Sunnyside and 65th S as well as the potential to serve larger future growth needs as the urbanized areas continue to extend to the south. Due to the South Expressway recommendation, 65th S was not initially recommended as a strategic arterial, but rather was recommended to become a minor arterial with a 3-lane cross section. The Old Butte Road Corridor was recommended for inclusion as a strategic arterial as this corridor completes an inner loop connection and provides support for the more near-term development likely to occur west of the Snake River. All other proposed strategic arterials corridors were included in the initial recommended high-capacity roadway system. In addition, 5th W (Freeman Rd/E River Rd) north of US 20 showed capacity issues under 2050 conditions, and is recommended to be upgraded from a Minor Arterial to a Major Arterial from US 20 to 65th N. The full initial recommended scenario is shown in Figure 12. HIGH-CAPACITY ROADWAY STUDY • ALTERNATIVES MEMORANDUM • AUGUST 2024 24 FIGURE 12: INITIAL HIGH-CAPACITY ROADWAY SYSTEM HIGH-CAPACITY ROADWAY STUDY • ALTERNATIVES MEMORANDUM • AUGUST 2024 25 The traffic benefits of the Initial High-Capacity Roadway scenario were evaluated by adding the proposed expressways and strategic arterials to the 2050 Baseline Scenario. The change in daily traffic volume between the year 2050 Initial High-Capacity Roadway and the Baseline Scenario was mapped along with the ADT and LOS (See Figure 13 and Figure 14). FIGURE 13: INITIAL HIGH-CAPACITY SYSTEM VS BASELINE 2050 TRAFFIC VOLUME CHANGE HIGH-CAPACITY ROADWAY STUDY • ALTERNATIVES MEMORANDUM • AUGUST 2024 26 FIGURE 14: INITIAL HIGH-CAPACITY SYSTEM ADT AND LOS As shown in Figure 14, the initial High-Capacity System improves several corridors, including Sunnyside Road, 65th S, Iona Road, and 45th E. Key system performance metrics are summarized in Table 4. HIGH-CAPACITY ROADWAY STUDY • ALTERNATIVES MEMORANDUM • AUGUST 2024 27 TABLE 4: CONGESTED LANE MILES SUMMARY YEAR % LANE MILES LOS E % LANE MILES LOS F % LANE MILES DEFICIENT (LOS E AND F) 2022 - EXISTING 2.6% 1.9% 4.5% 2050 - BASELINE 8.3% 6.9% 15.2% 2050 – INITIAL HIGH-CAPACITY ROADWAY SYSTEM 7.2% 5.8% 13.0% The Initial High-Capacity System area wide benefits are somewhat muted by the capacity constraints of the existing strategic arterial corridors. These corridors do have opportunities for additional capacity enhancement, particularly with coordinated signal timings on the signalized corridors, and widening on to existing five-lane segments at key locations. These proposed corridors will help keep the regional traffic movements off the local system, enhancing opportunities for parallel low stress active transportation corridors, reduce the risk of neighborhood cut-through traffic attempting to bypass arterial congestion, and provide opportunities for safer transit access. Additional evaluation at the corridor level considered the traffic operations benefits of limiting future access to the strategic arterial corridors as the surrounding areas develop and build out. These benefits were estimated based on the proportion of each corridor currently undeveloped, and the Highway Capacity Manual (HCM) travel time and segment density (congestion) reductions associated with reduced access. Existing corridors surrounded by more built out adjacent land uses realize less future benefit, as many of the access decisions on the urban segments of these corridors have already been made. FINAL HIGH-CAPACITY ROADWAY NETWORK The input received from local jurisdictions throughout the BMPA indicated ROW and land use constraints that rendered the West Expressway alternative inviable. The Causes of Traffic and Congestion
There are many misconceptions in my local conversation about what does or does not induce motor traffic. Some of these misconceptions are:
Single family homes do not increase traffic. If all we build are single-family homes, this will forever stay a quiet neighborhood.
Commercial development does not increase traffic, because it does not add more residents.
Congestion is bad, and we should treat avoiding it as a priority.
Let's dive into it: traffic, what causes it, and what we can do about it.
The Role of the Street Network
Hierarchy of roads. (Source: Wikipedia)
The largest contributor to congestion is the hierarchical road network. This is where you have local streets feed into collectors that feed into arterials that feed into highways.
The Strong Towns article on Dealing with Congestion explains why this is bad. We are funneling all traffic through a small number of streets, giving us a lower vehicle capacity as well as fewer redundancies for when things go wrong (creating a fragile road network where one clog can grind traffic to a halt), and artificially spaces things out by reducing what you can reach in a given distance (sometimes stupidly so as in the case where two houses share a backyard despite their front doors being 7 miles apart).
A highly connected street network (this can mean a grid, but can also take non-geometric forms such as the street network of a medieval city) is better because there are a ton of redundancies (a street closure does not matter if you have countless alternative routes from A to B) and distances are shorter as you can take a more direct route from A to B. Because the load is distributed over the many redundancies, we are no longer funneling all of the traffic over a small handful of collectors or arterials, so you are going to encounter less traffic along your way, even if all else (population density, amount of travel) remains equal.
I took this photo of the crowd at the train station just outside of the MetLife Stadium while waiting in a crowd myself trying to just get outside. No matter how frequently the train comes, attempting to funnel all of these people through a single point is going to feel extremely crowded.
Designating a main thoroughfare, with higher speed and greater capacity, to funnel traffic through is bad, even if it is part of a street grid. This thoroughfare will attract all of the traffic until it is so congested that it no longer offers a speed advantage over alternative routes (such as parallel side streets), and all people will do is complain how congested it is. This holds true any time we deal with funneling a flow: getting all cars to take the same road, asking all spectators to leave through the same stadium door after a sports game, making all travelers at the airport to go through a single security line, pushing all commuters onto a single transit line, getting all permit approvals to flow through a single queue, and so on. It does not take many people for it to feel crowded when everyone is concentrated in one place.
The Role of Land Use
Let's look at land use. It is true that not having anything will attract no traffic (there is nobody living there and nowhere to go, so there will be no traffic), thus building anything will increase traffic. But the correlation between the amount of activity in a place (residences, businesses, and other destinations) and the traffic it produces is not linear.
The trick comes down to building complete neighborhoods. A complete neighborhood is one where you can get most of your needs within walking distance. Transitioning to a complete neighborhood reduces motor traffic because of import replacement.
Import replacement refers to the practice of replacing a good or service that you used to get elsewhere with a local good or service. Import replacement takes many forms. The word ‘import’ makes me think of foreign trade, so the first thing that comes to mind when I hear ‘import replacement’ is replacing imported washing machines from China with domestic washing machines. However, import replacement can occur at different levels (all the way down to the neighborhood), and can refer to the replacement of non-physical goods. For example, a small town might not have its own advertising agency, so local businesses have to use the services of an advertising agency in a larger city. But, as that small town grows, it is likely that local businesses (such as advertising agencies, law firms, doctors’ clinics, building contractors, shops, and restaurants) will emerge and residents can avoid traveling to the next town over.
Let’s look at a specific example. If a city does not have a Mexican restaurant, its residents, if they want Mexican food, are required to travel 20 miles to the next town. But, Mexican food is popular so the residents make the trek. The city decides to open its own Mexican restaurant. Now, if you want Mexican food you only have to make a 2 mile trip instead of a 20 mile trip. So, you could argue there are more cars in the city (since the cars are not leaving for the next town over), but you are going to encounter less traffic for two reasons:
You are only traveling 2 miles and not 20 miles, so you’re going to spend less time in your car and dealing with traffic.
If your town has some form of a highly-connected street network (such as a street grid or an organic mesh), it will better distribute the load of traffic than funneling everyone through a few regional connections between the cities.
Let’s go one step further. If a Mexican restaurant opens 3 blocks from where we live, do we even need a vehicle (car or transit) to get to the Mexican restaurant? Would it not be easier just to walk or ride a bike? And save dealing with parking or waiting for the bus/train for those longer trips?
I love Strong Towns’s party analogy. Imagine that you are hosting a party outdoors at a park. Everyone who attends is required to bring more food or drink than they consume. If someone showed up, you would say, “Come on in!” because the more people, the more food, the better the party. This is a Good Party. Now imagine the opposite. You are providing the food and drink, the more people who show up, the less there is to go around (or the more you are spending). If someone unexpected shows up, you would send them away, because the more people, the worse the party. This is a Bad Party. A Good Party gets better with more people. A Bad Party gets worse with more people.
In terms of traffic, if you keep your land uses segregated, especially at car-scales, with your residents in one area and your businesses in another area, the more people you add, the more traffic there will be as more people travel between the two sides. This is a Bad Party. You do not want more people. You do not want more traffic.
On the other hand, if your city allows a mixture of uses within neighborhoods, then the more people who show up, the more likely it is that you will get that Mexican restaurant 3 blocks from you, as well as other amenities. This is a Good Party. The more the merrier.
Several years ago I made a Zoning and Traffic simulator where I measured the effect of traffic and land uses. My take away from that is:
1. Separating land uses generates congestion.
2. Cities have a tendency to order themselves so that the most dense stuff is in the middle, and the least dense stuff is around the outside, and this results in less congestion and shorter average commute times.
3. A heuristic approach (letting the free market optimize itself through trial and error) works quite well, and can cut commute times in half and results in less congestion. If this fails and you end up with randomized land use, then you end up with slightly shorter commute times and significantly less congestion than segregating land uses anyway.
The Role of Density
Hoboken’s Washington Street. Monday, at 5:45PM.
By building Complete Neighborhoods, we can approach high population densities with little motor traffic. For example, Hoboken, where I live, has a population of about 40,000 people per square mile, and yet even during rush hour, our main street, Washington Street, has very little traffic. There are still people who drive to work—either they commute a long distance off the beaten path of transit or they are contractors who have a van full of tools—but transit, walking, and cycling are serious modes of transportation only because we’ve built and connected together complete neighborhoods.
Let's look at an extreme case—Manhattan—which is an island of complete neighborhoods (some of which reach population densities up to about 151,000 people per square mile). Cars only account for 6% of trips in Manhattan (this number from NYCDOT excludes the northern area of Manhattan above Central Park). I am not under the illusion that Manhattan has no motor traffic or that by doing everything right you can eliminate all traffic. But observing traffic in Manhattan, I notice several interesting properties:
A typical residential street does not have that much traffic.
When there is traffic, at least half of the non-parked vehicles are commercial vehicles (cars with Uber stickers on their window, taxis, buses, garbage trucks, delivery vans, etc.)
Traffic seems to be the heaviest when it gets concentrated on designated thoroughfares such as 11th Avenue.
Traffic lights create an illusion of congestion because they create synchronization barriers that cause vehicles otherwise spaced apart to cluster together (and then continue on travelling as a cluster). I don't like traffic lights.
Video of the traffic at the intersection of Manhattan's 10th Avenue and 23rd Street at lunch. Not bad for a neighborhood of 145,000 people per square mile.
One thing we can say with a high degree of certainty is that if Manhattan did not have a subway system or was not made up of complete neighborhoods, traffic would be far worse if we had an additional 5.6 million daily car commuters on the street, not to mention all the small trips done on foot (such as walking to the doctor, shopping, or going out to eat) that would be otherwise done in a car. Once you reach this point where Manhattan is today, there is not much you can do, in regards to the development pattern, to reduce traffic. But the vast majority of American cities are not at this point.
Another way we can work to reduce vehicular traffic is to simultaneously disincentivize driving by taking away space from cars (travel lanes, parking) or congestion pricing, while incentivizing other modes (expanding the transit system, expanding bike sharing, etc.) enough that these other modes become the more convenient choice.
Is congestion really a problem?
At the end of the day, we should not worry too much about congestion or traffic. Congestion is part of the solution, not the problem. Congestion is feedback that we have built a place people want to be. The response to congestion should be to allow that Mexican restaurant to open up 3 blocks away rather than 2 miles away. To create bus lines and bike lanes that give people alternative ways to get around. The incorrect response to congestion is to build faster and wider streets, because that just reinforces car dependency and all of the negative consequences that come with it.
To summarize:
Development can add traffic. However, development that brings amenities and people closer together and reduces the need to travel so far can actually reduce traffic. With a mixture of uses, you can achieve a high population density with very little motor traffic.
A highly-connected street network (either a street grid or organic) with many redundancies better distributes the load of traffic and is more resilient to disruptions.
Designated thoroughfares and bypasses create an illusion of traffic because they funnel the traffic through a single point (and with this comes the fragility of a single point of failure that can bring down the system).
Attempting to address congestion with solutions that make it easier to drive can make the problem worse by continuing to make the car the preferred way to get around.
We should not worry too much about congestion, because it creates demand for other modes of transportation and for amenities to be closer.
Part of why we can't agree on constructive solutions to traffic congestion is that our basic mental model of what causes traffic is wrong. But what if we made a slight update to that model?
These observations from a morning detour demonstrate why small neighborhood side streets are better than big, wide highways, even when it comes to moving traffic.
No, you’re not stuck in congestion because your city’s infrastructure is “inadequate” to handle growth.
Not for the first time, the Car-pocalypse failed to materialize around Seattle’s new SR-99 tunnel. This is further proof we’ve been underestimating commuters’ ability to adjust to transportation changes. Have we also been overestimating how much they value these multibillion-dollar megaprojects in the first place?
Flawed methodology. Lack of accountability. Discrepant data. Egregious assumptions. The new Urban Mobility Report will be used to make or justify transportation policies around the country, which makes it too wrong to be ignored. 
Love to hate congestion? We’ll never fix it by obsessing over speed or traffic delays. We need to rethink our whole transportation debate, starting with this premise: it’s not about how fast you can go. It’s about what you can get to.
A deep, dredged ship canal is a recipe for catastrophic flooding in a hurricane, whereas a coastal marsh absorbs the surge of water in a way that lets life continue to flourish. This analogy has something important to teach us about urban streets.
Once a year, Ben & Jerry’s gives away ice cream for free—and people line up around the block because the price is so low. There’s a lesson here about urban roads and congestion.
We’ve gotten very good at keeping traffic off of neighborhood streets. But at what cost to our cities?
When we obsess over the speed of travel—whether in our cars or on public transit—we’re missing the point of transportation. It’s not about how far you can get in a given time: it’s what you can get to.
Andrew Price (Twitter: @AndrewAPrice) has been a regular contributor to Strong Towns since 2013 and is a founding member of the organization. Andrew is a software developer by day and an urbanist by night. He is passionate about traditional urbanism – he believes in fine-grained, highly walkable places that are built for people. He grew up in Australia and now lives in the United States with his wife. Andrew is a regular contributor on Strong Towns and runs his own blog, andrewalexanderprice.com. You can find many of his photographs throughout the Strong Towns website. Andrew’s motivation to be involved in Strong Towns and urbanism is to create a great place that he and his wife, and one day their children and their future generations will want to call home.

document1.context: Forecasted percentage increase in delay per trip by 2050

document2.context: Percentage reduction in traffic due to complete neighborhoods

tasks.question: If the traffic delay per trip in the BMPO Area is increased by 82% by 2050, and this increase can be reduced by 50% due to the implementation of complete neighborhoods, what will be the effective percentage increase in traffic delay per trip?
tasks.solution:
def solve():
    # Given values
    initial_delay_increase = 82.0  # Percentage increase in delay per trip by 2050
    reduction_due_to_complete_neighborhoods = 50.0  # Percentage reduction
    
    # Calculate the effective increase
    effective_delay_increase = initial_delay_increase * (1 - reduction_due_to_complete_neighborhoods / 100)
    
    answer = effective_delay_increase
    return answer

Subtopic: Effect of Traffic Regulations on Flow Efficiency

Dive Brief
Traffic congestion is worse now than before the pandemic: Streetlight Data report
Despite remote or hybrid work and empty offices, people are driving more. “The status quo isn’t working,” the report says.
Published Sept. 19, 2024

Dan Zukowski Senior Reporter

 post
 share
 post
 print
 email
 license


Pedestrians and cars move through midtown Manhattan traffic on June 6, 2024, in New York City. The city's urban center saw the largest increase in vehicle miles traveled and traffic congestion from 2019 to 2024 compared with other top metropolitan areas’ downtowns in the U.S. Spencer Platt via Getty Images
 Listen to the article 2 min
This audio is auto-generated. Please let us know if you have feedback.
Dive Brief:

Traffic congestion is greater today than in 2019 in all but six of the top 100 most populous metropolitan areas in the U.S., according to a report published this month from Streetlight Data.
Despite hybrid and remote work trends, the number of vehicle miles traveled per capita was 12% higher in May 2024 than the same month in 2019.
In downtown areas, although vehicle miles traveled are lower in 18 of the 25 most highly populated cities, congestion is down in just eight of them, implying that “congestion is quite stubborn on these taxed urban roads,” the report says.

Dive Insight:
Prior to the COVID-19 pandemic, the number of daily vehicle miles traveled per capita was on an upward trend nationwide, the report says. Initially, amid stay-at-home orders and work-from-home policies, VMT dropped dramatically. But from its low in the spring of 2020, VMT across the U.S. climbed upward.
Vehicle miles traveled and traffic congestion can correlate with one another but not in all cases. Among the top 25 cities, five kept their VMT at or below 2019 levels but only San Francisco saw congestion slightly under its pre-pandemic mark. Focusing on downtown areas — many of which are struggling with empty office buildings — the Streetlight Data report found just seven of the urban cores in the top 25 metropolitan areas experienced lower congestion than in 2019.
New York City’s urban center saw both the largest rise in VMT and in congestion, even as office vacancy rates hover around 16% in Manhattan, according to the New York City comptroller. New York City would have become the first city in the U.S. to establish a congestion pricing program to address its traffic problem, but New York Gov. Kathy Hochul pulled the plug on the plan in June.
“While there was some hope that a new remote work culture might keep miles driven down and congestion at bay, StreetLight’s results indicate that the status quo isn’t working,” the report says. “A reliance on remote work is not a panacea to the rise in VMT and the default solution for traffic — adding roadway capacity — isn’t solving congestion.”
Recommended Reading

Congestion pricing alone won’t solve New York’s traffic problem By Ralf-Peter Schäfer • Aug. 6, 2024

Clean & Safe: New speed limits in Santa Monica prioritize roadway safety for all users
August 29, 2024 7:59 AM
SANTA MONICA, Calif. (Aug. 28, 2024) – Speed limits on more than 30 miles of Santa Monica streets will be lowered, following unanimous approval by the Santa Monica City Council on Tuesday.   
These reductions are the results of a speed survey conducted earlier this year to ensure the speed limits remain valid. The survey, conducted from Jan. 27 through Jul. 29, includes measurement of vehicular speeds along roadway segments to determine the speed of a majority of drivers, which is the most effective attribute in establishing speed limits.

The study recommended only one increase in speed limit, from 25 to 30 miles per hour, on a 0.3-mile segment of California Avenue. A full list of approved speed adjustments, recommended in consultation with the Santa Monica Police Department, is included below.  
The city will begin rolling out new signage exhibiting the updated speed limits this fall.  
The proposed speed limit changes support the city’s Vision Zero goal of eliminating fatal and severe injury crashes on city streets by improving safety for all roadway users.   
Council adopted Vision Zero in February 2016. Unsafe speed is the second most common violation cited in fatal and severe crashes in the city, at 14 percent of the total. Crashes at slower speeds are less likely to result in fatalities, and the application of reasonable and safe speed limits allows for effective enforcement of speed limits throughout the city.  
 “Reducing vehicle speeds on our roads is vital to create safer conditions for getting around in our city,” Department of Transportation Director Anuj Gupta said. “It is one of the many ways Santa Monica is creating a street network that is more safe, connected and attractive for all roadway users.”  
The ordinance will be adopted 30 days after the second reading, which is anticipated for Sept. 10. For more information, view the staff report here.

tasks.question: In 2024, if you multiply the office vacancy rate in Manhattan by the miles of streets with reduced speed limits in Santa Monica, then subtract the percentage of fatal crashes due to unsafe speed in Santa Monica, what is the result?
tasks.solution:
def solve():
    # Extracted numerical values
    office_vacancy_rate = 16  # Office vacancy rate in Manhattan in 2024
    reduced_speed_miles = 30  # Miles of streets with reduced speed limits in Santa Monica
    unsafe_speed_percentage = 14  # Percentage of fatal crashes due to unsafe speed in Santa Monica

    # Step 1: Calculate the product of the office vacancy rate and reduced speed miles
    product = office_vacancy_rate * reduced_speed_miles

    # Step 2: Subtract the unsafe speed percentage from the product
    answer = product - unsafe_speed_percentage

    return answer

Traffic is worse now than before the pandemic: Here's where people drive the most
By FOX TV Digital Team
Published  September 25, 2024 11:18am CDT
Transportation
Fox TV Stations
Share

Copy Link
Email
Facebook
Twitter
LinkedIn
Reddit

 article
FILE - Heavy traffic on the 580 Freeway in Dublin, California, in the San Francisco Bay Area, August 3, 2024. (Photo by Smith Collection/Gado/Getty Images)
The Brief



Traffic in most major cities is worse now than it was before the pandemic, a new report finds.
Adding more roadways doesn’t appear to be solving the problem.



Traffic congestion and the amount of daily driving in America is worse now than it was before the pandemic, according to a report from Streetlight Data.
The report, which analyzes traffic congestion and VMT (vehicle miles traveled) in major U.S. metros, found that as of spring 2024, the number of miles Americans are driving has jumped – and the increase in VMT in spring 2024 compared to spring 2023 marks the steepest year-over-year increase since the initial pandemic bounce back in 2021.
"While there was some hope that a new remote work culture might keep miles driven down and congestion at bay, StreetLight’s results indicate that the status quo isn’t working," the report says. "A reliance on remote work is not a panacea to the rise in VMT and the default solution for traffic—adding roadway capacity—isn’t solving congestion.
"Without significant changes, the upward trend in VMT shows no signs of peaking."
READ MORE: Lyft to downsize, restructure bike and scooter program
New York City saw the biggest increase in miles traveled and congestion over the past five years, while Minneapolis had the biggest decrease in congestion and a 16% decrease in miles traveled.
According to the report, 88 of the top 100 metros in the U.S. showed an increase in VMT from spring 2019-spring 2024. Only four metros saw double-digit decreases.
Congestion is also up in nearly every metro, with only six of the top 100 metros keeping congestion at or below levels seen in 2019, the report found.
US cities where people drive the most
The 10 metros where people tend to drive the most are concentrated in the Southeast, Streetlight found.
"These are places with sprawling geographies and often limited public transit availability," the report states.
The Northeast, Northwest and California ranked as the regions where people drive the least – people in the Southeast drive nearly twice as far as people in those regions.
RELATED: These aging bridges will be updated, replaced with the help of $5 billion in federal funding
California had five cities with VMT below 2019 levels. The only other large city to accomplish that is Washington, D.C.
New York, Washington, and California are home to nine of the top 10 metros with the lowest daily VMT per capita.
US cities with the most traffic congestion
Not surprisingly, Los Angeles ranked worst for overall congestion, despite a decrease in VMT being down.
"While VMT reduction has not yet translated to a reduction in congestion, LA has managed to keep traffic from worsening, unlike most of its peers," the report says.
READ MORE: Pedestrian deaths declining since COVID-19 pandemic, report finds
New York City, meanwhile, saw its congestion worsen faster in the past five years than the next 47 most populous cities.
San Francisco was ranked as the top metro for congestion reduction while also reducing daily VMT per capita by 13%.
The Source

This story includes information from Streetlight Data.

Texas A&M Transportation Institute
Transportation Policy Research
Variable Speed Limits
How Will This Help | Target Market | Implementation Examples | References
Introduction
As speed limits are currently set for the maximum safe speed on roadways, variable speed limits (VSLs) use speed limit signs that change to slow drivers to avoid creating heavy traffic congestion. Sensors along the roadway detect when congestion or weather conditions are dangerous. They then automatically reduce the speed limit (in at least 5-mph increments) to slow traffic evenly to allow smooth traffic flow, delay the onset of congestion, and avoid stop-and-go conditions. VSLs are also called speed harmonization and dynamic speed limits.
Contrary to what one may think, slowing traffic down in heavy traffic actually increases the number of cars that can travel on a road.  The slower speeds make drivers more comfortable driving closer together and keep stop-and-go conditions to a minimum.
Depending on the purpose of the system, speed limits can be mandatory or suggested. Changeable message signs can also be used with this system to give drivers travel-time information or other details.
The ideal system monitors data from roadway sensors and automatically adjusts speed limits when congestion reaches a certain amount. The speed limit is lowered to keep an even traffic flow at a speed that is reasonable with the traffic volume. This delays the start of stop-and-go conditions and reduces the number of rear-end collisions.
Two common purposes for using VSLs are for bad weather conditions and congestion management:
In both cases, the speed limit decrease is intended to alert drivers of conditions up ahead. Ideally, the speed limit and message alerts are automated and do not require intervention from an operator. VSLs are commonly used with automated traffic warning and lane control signs. They are also regularly combined with temporary shoulder use.

Target Market
How Will This Help?
Implementation Examples
Sydney, Australia
Sydney, Australia, implemented a fog warning system that includes suggested speeds. During fog, the suggested speed limit is constantly adjusted to the speed of the previous vehicle (but no higher than the speed limit).1
Denmark
In Denmark, studies found the following.
The VSL signs also reduced speed variance.2
The Netherlands
The Netherlands also uses VSLs for weather conditions. Visibility sensors measure the level of fog, and when visibility drops to 459 or 230 ft (140 or 70 m), the speed limit is dropped to 50 or 37 mph (80 or 60 km/h), respectively. After implementation of the VSL during fog conditions, drivers reduced their speed by 5.0–6.2 mph (8–10 km/h).3
The Netherlands is examining speed limits through a dynamic speed limit project. The project was developed “to gain more insight into the impact of variable, tailor-made speed limits.”8 A pamphlet on VSLs provides the following details on the benefits:
Adjusting speed limits to unexpected and varying situations such as weather conditions, congestion, or an incident can improve traffic flow. It will also enhance the safety and improve local air quality. By applying a flexible and wide range of speed limits (50 to 120 km/h [31 to 75 mph]) operators can influence the actual situation on the road. Thus road users can drive faster if possible and slow down if necessary.8
An evaluation of permanent speed reduction showed excellent compliance (approximately 1 percent violators) due to enforcement. Reductions in emissions and noise level were also noted. Residents along the routes expressed thanks for the change.
The evaluation of VSLs in the Netherlands is currently ongoing. Researchers are exploring how to use data from traffic-monitoring equipment to assist in detecting shockwaves and then to manage upstream speeds to limit the impact of the shockwave. A system called Speed Controlling Algorithm Using Shockwave Theory (Specialist) is being developed. Weather forecasts (e.g., a major rainstorm) are also considered when setting the VSLs.9
United Kingdom
Using VSLs during heavy traffic, the United Kingdom saw:
In England, the Managed Motorways concept was deployed on the M42 roadway. The figure below shows compliance with the required VSL.10 The graph starts with data from January 2006 and ends with data from May 2009. In late 2007 to early 2009, the required speed limit was set at 50 mph when hard shoulder running was allowed. During this time, compliance was not as good as when the speed limit was set to 60 mph during hard shoulder running (started in early 2009). Drivers did not see the reason for the lower speed and thus drove at the higher speeds. This behavior is also shown in the decline in compliance when the speed limit was set to 40 mph.
Germany
On roads with VSLs in Germany:
Denmark
In Denmark, VSLs resulted in decreased speeds of less than 5 km/h and reduced speed variance. A survey showed that 46 percent of Danish travelers felt safer after the changes.7
Texas
The Texas Department of Transportation (TxDOT), with the assistance of the Texas A&M Transportation Institute (TTI), currently operates a VSL pilot program. This program has VSL pilot studies in three locations (the Brownwood, Waco, and San Antonio Districts) to gauge the impacts and potential benefits of VSLs in two instances:
TTI is analyzing the impacts of the VSL on travel speeds, safety, users’ perceptions, and costs and benefits. Researchers provided TxDOT with a report that was made available to the Texas Legislature in December 2014.
Application Techniques and Principles
General conditions for VSL systems include:
The following are key factors to consider for successful deployment:
Issues
This strategy has been successful in Europe but is new to the United States. Public acceptance and understanding of the system are crucial to its success. Drivers must understand why the speed limit is being reduced and that the reason is valid. All drivers must understand whether the new speed limit is suggested or required. A system that automatically changes the speed display ensures that changes take place before stop-and-go traffic begins to occur. Also, the speed limit signs have to be visible to all vehicles.
Who Is Responsible?
The local TxDOT office and/or the regional mobility authority bears the responsibility of developing and maintaining VSLs. These agencies should:
Project Time Frame
The lengths of VSL projects differ based on the available infrastructure and amount of planning prior to starting. The systems should have ample connections to the local traffic center. Other supporting infrastructure and policies should also be in place. Since some additional signage will be required, a typical VSL deployment may take between one and two years to begin.
Cost
The cost of installing VSLs on a roadway varies depending on the existing infrastructure and the selection and spacing of overhead signs, changeable message signs, and other related signage.
Data Needs
The following standard traffic information helps determine the need for a VSL system:
 Variable Speed Limits Best Practices

tasks.question: If New York City's traffic congestion increased by 47% over five years and Minneapolis's traffic congestion decreased by 16% in Spring 2024, what is the combined percentage change in traffic congestion between these two cities over this period?
tasks.solution:
def solve():
    # Percentage increase in New York City
    nyc_congestion_increase = 47.0
    
    # Percentage decrease in Minneapolis
    minneapolis_congestion_decrease = 16.0
    
    # Combined change in congestion percentage
    combined_congestion_change = nyc_congestion_increase + (-minneapolis_congestion_decrease)
    
    answer = combined_congestion_change
